questions.text: A 40-year-old Engineer receives negative feedback on a recent project from his senior associate. He is told sternly that he must improve his performance on the next project. Later that day, he yells at his intern, a college student, for not showing enough initiative, though he had voiced only satisfaction with his performance up until this point. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Displacement Displacement (in psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual redirects negative emotions from their real target to a neutral third party. The neutral third party is often a subordinate or less threatening entity. The computer scientist is displacing his anger at his senior associate to his intern.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option : A . Projection (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her thoughts, emotions, or behavior to another individual(s). For example, the computer scientist had a poor performance because he was lazy; he attributes his student's poor performance to laziness as well when the student's poor performance could have been the result of ill health. Option : C . Countertransference is a term used in psychoanalysis to refer to the effect that the patient has on the psychotherapist. Countertransference is not a defense mechanism. Option : D . Reaction formation is a neurotic defense reaction in which an individual replaces an undesired idea or feeling by acting in a diametrically opposite fashion. For example, a nymphomaniac who becomes a nun, or a man who insults a woman because he is in love with her.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the outpatient mental health clinic at the request of her oncologist 3 weeks after being diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer. The patient denies strong feelings in relation to the diagnosis but talks a great deal about the epidemiology of breast cancer and the available treatment options. Which of the following defense mechanisms is she using?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intellectualization The control of effects and impulses by way of thinking about them instead of experiencing them. It is a systematic excess of thinking, deprived of its effect, to defend against anxiety caused by unacceptable impulses.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Sublimation is a defense mechanism employed to deal with unacceptable feelings or desires by channeling them into socially acceptable behaviors. Option: B. Dissociation is a defense mechanism that deals with stressors with a breakdown of the usual integration of memory, behavior, and perception. Option: D . Rationalization is a defense against undesired motivations, but in this case, the motivations are concealed by elaborate and reassuring explanations that avoid the actual underlying motives.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man after being severely reprimanded by his boss, goes home and is extremely nasty to his wife. What is his behavior an example of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Displacement Involves a purposeful, unconscious shifting of impulses or affective investment from one object to another in the interest of solving a conflict . Although the object is changed, the instinctual nature of the impulse and its aim remain unchanged. The man is naturally angry, anxious, and sensitive at being reprimanded by his employer. He has found it difficult to express his feelings toward the disturbing person, the employer, so he displaces his anger onto a safer target, his wife. This is an example of displacement.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Sublimation is a defense mechanism employed to deal with unacceptable feelings or desires by channeling them into socially acceptable behaviors. Option: B. Rationalization is a defense against undesired motivations, but in this case, the motivations are concealed by elaborate and reassuring explanations that avoid the actual underlying motives. Option: D. Intellectualization is the utilization of abstract thinking to deal with or cover internal or external stressors; in this case, the unacceptable feelings of having cancer.

questions.text: A 3.5-year-old girl goes to school for the first time. After she returns, she plays teacher-teacher with her friend. What does this demonstrate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Identification It is a psychic process in which a person takes on characteristics of another. It plays an important role in how oue personalities develop.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect option:- Option: B. Dissociation is a defense mechanism that deals with stressors with a breakdown of the usual integration of memory, behavior, and perception. Option: C. Sublimation is a defense mechanism employed to deal with unacceptable feelings or desires by channeling them into socially acceptable behaviors. Option: D. Intellectualization: The control of effects and impulses by way of thinking about them instead of experiencing them. It is a systematic excess of thinking, deprived of its effect, to defend against anxiety caused by unacceptable impulses.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has been smoking for 10 years. He refuses to admit to himself that smoking is bad for his health. Which defense mechanism is working here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Denial Seeing, but refusing to acknowledge what one sees, or hears and negating what is heard are examples of denial and exemplify the close relationship of denial to sensory experience. Denial avoids becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Dissociation is a temporary but drastic modification of character or sense of personal identity to avoid emotional distress; it includes fugue states and hysterical conversion reactions. Option: C. Distortion Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs, including unrealistic megalomanic beliefs, hallucinations, wish-fulfilling delusions, and employing sustained feelings of delusional grandiosity, superiority, or entitlement. Option: D. Rationalization A justification of attitudes, beliefs, or behavior that might otherwise be unacceptable by an incorrect application of justifying reasons or the invention of a convincing fallacy.

questions.text: A person has a fight with his employer in the office. When he came home, he was stressed. He wants to take out his anger on his wife but instead of this, he goes out running. Which defense mechanism is acting here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sublimation The gratification of an impulse whose goal is retained but whose aim or object is changed from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one , as in this case.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Rationalization-used to justify unaccepted beliefs, behavior, and attitude. Option: C. Distortion Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs, including unrealistic megalomaniac beliefs, hallucinations, wish-fulfilling delusions, and employing sustained feelings of delusional grandiosity, superiority, or entitlement. Option: D. Seeing, but refusing to acknowledge what one sees, or hears and negating what is heard are examples of denial.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man who is going to be retired within 2 years, plans for his retirement. He saved money and applied for health insurance. What is the defense mechanism acting here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anticipation The person does' future planning to deal with uncomfortable events. The realistic anticipation of or planning for future inner discomfort : Implies overly concerned planning, worrying, and anticipation of dire and dreadful possible outcomes.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Rationalization- used to justify unaccepted beliefs, behavior, and attitude Option: C. Altruism- Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual like for himself/ herself Option: D. Asceticism-Gratification derived from renunciation which is not seen in this case

questions.text: A person raises funds for an organization that creates awareness regarding road traffic rules. He says that his parents died in a car accident 5 years ago. Which defense mechanism acts here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Altruism He does constructive service for the welfare of others. This must be distinguished from altruistic surrender , which involves a masochistic surrender of direct gratification or instinctual needs in favor of fulfilling the needs of others to the detriment of the self, with vicarious satisfaction only being gained through introjection.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Seeing, but refusing to acknowledge what one sees, or hears and negating what is heard are examples of denial. Option: C. Asceticism-The elimination of directly pleasurable effects attributable to an experience. The moral element is implicit in setting values on specific pleasures. Option: D. Rationalization-used to justify unaccepted beliefs, behavio r, and attitude

questions.text: A 30-year-old man beats his wife very badly. When asked about the same, he says she doesn't do her household work properly and to make her understand, the beating was necessary. What is the defense mechanism acting here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rationalization He does wrong to his wife but he tries to justify it by giving reasons. A justification of attitudes, beliefs, or behavior that might otherwise be unacceptable by an incorrect application of justifying reasons is called rationalization.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Altruism-Getting pleasure from giving to others what one wants for himself. Option: C. Displacement-Involves a purposeful, unconscious shifting of impulses or affective investment from one object to another in the interest of solving a conflict. Option: D. Sublimation-impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is placed on probation at work and told that he must improve his performance to remain with the company. He is distraught and leaves his office early. When he told this to his wife, she says, “I'll always be proud of you no matter what because I know that you always try your best.” Later that night, he tearfully accuses her of believing that he is a failure. Which defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Projection Projection is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her thoughts, emotions, or behavior to another individual (or other individuals).

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Transference refers to the unconscious redirection of feelings (positive or negative) from a past experience (often from childhood) with one object to a current experience with another object that has a perceived or real similarity to the first object. Option: C. Denial involves a subconscious refusal to accept unpleasant aspects of reality. For example, the biochemist would demonstrate denial if he showed up for work even after having been fired. Option: D. Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual redirects negative emotions from their real target to a neutral third party . The neutral third party is often a subordinate or less threatening entity. For example, the biochemist might receive negative feedback and later yell at his intern, a college student, for not showing enough initiative.

questions.text: A person is annoyed with his co-worker for his eating habits. Instead of talking to him directly, he leaves a magazine article about annoying eating habits on his co-worker’s desk. Which defense mechanism the individual is demonstrating?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Passive aggression Passive aggression is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual expresses negative feelings toward someone in a non - confrontational way.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. In acting out, patients directly express unconscious wishes or conflicts through action to avoid being conscious of either the accompanying idea or the effect. Option: B . Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual redirects negative emotions from their real target to a neutral third party. The neutral third party is often a subordinate or less threatening entity. Option: D . Blocking is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual unconsciously and transiently inhibits the thought process.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension and dyslipidemia visits the physician for a routine checkup. He says he feels well. His BMI is 32 kg/m2. His BMI last year was 27 kg/m2. When asked about his diet, he says, “Being overweight runs in my family. Rather than fight it, I just try to enjoy myself and eat what I want.” Which defense mechanisms best describe this response?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rationalization Rationalization is a neurotic defense mechanism that involves offering excuses or rational explanations to justify behaviors , attitudes, or beliefs to avoid self-blame . The way in which this patient uses his family history of obesity as a rationale for overeating and his own weight is therefore an example of rationalization.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect answer:- Option: A. Denial is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual consciously avoids anxiety-provoking thoughts by refusing to accept reality. Option: C. Distortion is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual reshapes his/her perception of an external reality (e.g., an upsetting event) to suit his/her inner needs. An example of distortion (psychiatry) might be someone who maintains they were abandoned by their family when they actually ran away from home. Option: D. Intellectualization is an immature defense mechanism that refers to the excessive reliance on facts and logic to avoid acknowledging or confronting one's emotions (e.g., excessively investigating the pathophysiology of a terminal illness instead of reacting to the anxiety brought on by the diagnosis).

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has frequent sexual fantasies about female co-workers. When she is with her friends in public, she never misses an opportunity to make derogatory comments about same-sex couples she sees. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is she demonstrating?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reaction formation Reaction formation is a neurotic ego defense mechanism in which an individual responds to an undesired idea or feeling by acting in a manner that is diametrically opposed to their feelings. This individual criticizes same-sex couples instead of accepting the possibility that she might be attracted to women.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Sexualization is a neurotic defense mechanism that refers to an inappropriate imposition of sexual significance on a person : e.g., an office worker who will not stop talking about his female co-worker’s "assets" because she is outperforming him in the workplace. Option: C. Sublimation refers to the transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse or a detrimental emotion into an acceptable action: e.g., an individual who decides to focus on his/her career after a breakup. Option: D. Projection is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her thoughts, emotions, or behavior to the thoughts, emotions, or behavior of another individual: e.g., a philandering individual who thinks that his/her partner is also cheating on him/her.

questions.text: A senior resident receives negative feedback on a grand round presentation from his attending and is told that he must improve his performance. Later that day, he yells at his medical student for not showing enough initiative, though he had voiced only satisfaction with the student's performance up until this point. Which defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Displacement Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual redirects negative emotions from their real target to a neutral third party . The neutral third party is often a subordinate or less threatening entity. The senior resident is displacing his anger at his attending to his medical student.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Transference refers to the unconscious redirection of feelings from a past experience with one object to a current experience with another object that has a perceived or real similarity to the first object . For example, the senior resident decides to yell at an intern who unconsciously reminds him of a former classmate who used to bully him in school. Option: C. Countertransference is a term used in psychoanalysis to refer to the effect that the patient has on the psychotherapist. Countertransference is not a defense mechanism. Option: D. Projection (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her thoughts, emotions, or behavior to the thoughts, emotions, or behavior of another individual(s). For example, the senior resident had a poor performance because he was lazy; he attributes the student's poor performance to laziness as well when the student's poor performance could actually have been the result of ill health.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has a very important essay due in 2 weeks that will play a big part in determining her final grades. She decides to focus on writing this essay instead and not worry about her grades until her essay is completed. Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains her behavior?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suppression Suppression, a mature defense mechanism, refers to intentionally or consciously choosing not to think about a feeling or thought that provokes anxiety.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Repression involves the unconscious removal of unpleasant or distressing thoughts from conscious awareness. Repression is a neurotic defense mechanism, and like most ego defenses, it occurs involuntarily; for example, a victim of abuse who does not remember being mistreated. Option: B. Blocking may occur when the individual is under a lot of stress, similar to this woman. However, blocking is an immature defense mechanism, and it involves the transient, involuntary interruption of the thought process. For example, a person who suddenly forgets what he/she has to do next. Option: C. Dissociation is a neurotic defense mechanism that refers to a temporary, subconscious disruption of one's sense of self or personal identity in order to avoid dealing with emotions that may possibly be painful. For example, a person who was mugged recalls the incident as an out-of-body experience.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought by his mother because she is worried about his behavior. Yesterday, he was expelled from school after getting suspended 3 times for bullying and aggressive behavior toward his peers and teachers. In the past, he was a sincere student without any complaints. The mother first noticed this change in behavior 3 months ago, around the time at which she divorced. Which defense mechanisms best describe this patient's behavior?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acting out Acting out is a type of immature defense mechanism by which the individual copes with a stressor by performing an often extreme behavior (e.g., throwing tantrums, using drugs, committing crimes) to express repressed or unconscious feelings and thoughts.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Reaction formation is a neurotic defense mechanism in which the individual copes with a stressor by unconsciously transforming an unacceptable feeling or impulse into the polar opposite (e.g., a xenophobic person is extremely nice to foreigners). Option: C. Passive aggression is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual expresses aggression toward others in an indirect, non-confrontational manner (e.g., not returning phone calls or intentionally missing meetings). Option: D. Suppression is a mature defense mechanism by which the individual intentionally withholds attention from an anxiety-provoking thought (e.g., choosing not to worry about impending test results).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman diagnosed with borderline personality disorder thinks of her therapist as “the best person in the world.” Next week, the therapist says that he will be going on vacation. The patient then says that he is “the worst person in the world.” What is the defense mechanism that allows people to see others as either all good or all bad?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splitting Splitting occurs when an individual is unable to see others moderately; that is, people’s actions are either all good or all bad.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B. Intellectualization is a defense that utilizes excessive abstract thinking or generalizations to control threatening emotions. Option: C. Repression is a defense that expels disturbing wishes, thoughts, or experiences from conscious awareness. Option: D. Idealization is a defense that attributes excessive positive qualities to another.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man had been repeatedly brutalized and slapped by his alcoholic mother throughout childhood and early adolescence. He felt humiliated afterward. One evening while they were drinking at a local tavern, a friend playfully slapped his cheek. The patient suddenly “saw red,” broke a beer bottle over the man’s head, and then mauled him severely. Which defense mechanism is this patient with intermittent explosive disorder exhibiting?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Identification with the aggressor Identification with the aggressor is a common defense mechanism, in which the explosive violence of a parent or close relative is internalized.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option A - Regression is a return to a previous stage of development or functioning to avoid the anxieties involved in later stages. Option B - Reaction formation is the management of unacceptable impulses by permitting the expression of the impulse in an antithetical form. Option C - Passive-aggressive behavior is aggression toward an object expressed indirectly and ineffectively through passivity, masochism, and turning against the self.
